TypeSignature.Value: .class public sequential ansi serializable sealed beforefieldinit RSAParameters extends System.ValueType

Docs.summary: アルゴリズムの標準のパラメーターを表します。

remarks.format:
## 解説 The <xref:System.Security.Cryptography.RSA> class exposes an <xref:System.Security.Cryptography.RSA.ExportParameters%2A> method that enables you to retrieve the raw RSA key in the form of an <xref:System.Security.Cryptography.RSAParameters> structure. Understanding the contents of this structure requires familiarity with how the <xref:System.Security.Cryptography.RSA> algorithm works. The next section discusses the algorithm briefly.
## RSA Algorithm To generate a key pair, you start by creating two large prime numbers named **math tag is not supported!!!!** and **math tag is not supported!!!!** . These numbers are multiplied and the result is called **math tag is not supported!!!!** . Because **math tag is not supported!!!!** and **math tag is not supported!!!!** are both prime numbers, the only factors of **math tag is not supported!!!!** are 1, **math tag is not supported!!!!** , **math tag is not supported!!!!** , and **math tag is not supported!!!!** .
If we consider only numbers that are less than **math tag is not supported!!!!** , the count of numbers that are relatively prime to **math tag is not supported!!!!** , that is, have no factors in common with **math tag is not supported!!!!** , equals **math tag is not supported!!!!** .
Now you choose a number **math tag is not supported!!!!** , which is relatively prime to the value you calculated. The public key is now represented as **math tag is not supported!!!!** .
To create the private key, you must calculate **math tag is not supported!!!!** , which is a number such that **math tag is not supported!!!!** . In accordance with the Euclidean algorithm, the private key is now **math tag is not supported!!!!** .
Encryption of plaintext **math tag is not supported!!!!** to ciphertext **math tag is not supported!!!!** is defined as **math tag is not supported!!!!** . Decryption would then be defined as **math tag is not supported!!!!** .
## Summary of Fields Section A.1.2 of the [PKCS \#1: RSA Cryptography Standard](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=113155) on the RSA Laboratories Web site defines a format for RSA private keys.
The following table summarizes the fields of the <xref:System.Security.Cryptography.RSAParameters> structure. The third column provides the corresponding field in section A.1.2 of [PKCS \#1: RSA Cryptography Standard](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=113155).
|<xref:System.Security.Cryptography.RSAParameters> field|Contains|Corresponding PKCS \#1 field| |---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|--------------|----------------------------------| |<xref:System.Security.Cryptography.RSAParameters.D>|d, the private exponent|privateExponent| |<xref:System.Security.Cryptography.RSAParameters.DP>|d mod \(p \- 1\)|exponent1| |<xref:System.Security.Cryptography.RSAParameters.DQ>|d mod \(q \- 1\)|exponent2| |<xref:System.Security.Cryptography.RSAParameters.Exponent>|e, the public exponent|publicExponent| |<xref:System.Security.Cryptography.RSAParameters.InverseQ>|\(InverseQ\)\(q\) \= 1 mod p|coefficient| |<xref:System.Security.Cryptography.RSAParameters.Modulus>|n|modulus| |<xref:System.Security.Cryptography.RSAParameters.P>|p|prime1| |<xref:System.Security.Cryptography.RSAParameters.Q>|q|prime2|
The security of RSA derives from the fact that, given the public key **math tag is not supported!!!!** , it is computationally infeasible to calculate **math tag is not supported!!!!** , either directly or by factoring **math tag is not supported!!!!** into **math tag is not supported!!!!** and **math tag is not supported!!!!** . Therefore, any part of the key related to **math tag is not supported!!!!** , **math tag is not supported!!!!** , or **math tag is not supported!!!!** must be kept secret. If you call
<xref:System.Security.Cryptography.RSACryptoServiceProvider.ExportParameters%2A> and ask for only the public key information, this is why you will receive only <xref:System.Security.Cryptography.RSAParameters.Exponent> and <xref:System.Security.Cryptography.RSAParameters.Modulus>. The other fields are available only if you have access to the private key, and you request it.
<xref:System.Security.Cryptography.RSAParameters> is not encrypted in any way, so you must be careful when you use it with the private key information. In fact, none of the fields that contain private key information can be serialized. If you try to serialize an <xref:System.Security.Cryptography.RSAParameters> structure with a remoting call or by using one of the serializers, you will receive only public key information. If you want to pass private key information, you will have to manually send that data. In all cases, if anyone can derive the parameters, the key that you transmit becomes useless.
